docs.lead_paragraph: Overcoming one of the last major hurdles to an accord on the state's record-setting late budget, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders reached a tentative agreement late Sunday night on sweeping legislation to end New York State's decades-old practice of setting rates for hospital services. They also agreed to extend for four days a law protecting thousands of loft tenants in New York City while negotiations continue this week on the budget. The loft law, which is not part of the budget but has been held hostage to the negotiations, had been set to expire at midnight.

headline.main: Albany Accord Over Hospitals Propels Budget

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to make dealing with the government easier for New Jersey's 1.4 million older adults, more than 20 state programs for the elderly will be consolidated under one new agency today: the Department of Health and Senior Services, formerly the Department of Health. A department spokeswoman, Rita Manno, said the move would make it easier to handle $1.5 billion worth of services in such areas as Medicaid and the institutionalized elderly, which until now have been supervised by separate officials in the departments of health, insurance, human services and community affairs.

keywords.value: HEALTH AND SENIOR SERVICES, DEPARTMENT OF

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of a quirk in the Federal Medicare law, elderly people are being required to pay more than their normal share of the bill for hospital outpatient services. It is far more than Congress originally intended and the burden is rising rapidly as such services account for a larger portion of all health care in the United States. Beneficiaries are ordinarily responsible for 20 percent of the cost of services under Part B of the Medicare program. But because of the law, they are now responsible, on average, for 37 percent of the total payments to hospitals for outpatient services, one of the most important benefits under Part B, according to a recent report to Congress by a Federal advisory panel.

headline.main: Quirk in Medicare Law Yields Bigger Bills for Outpatient Care
